subject: Re: why LOW IT and not LOW EAT for -ly?

messageBody:
I find this conversation interesting as I speak RP much as KR did. I will always write unstressed -i with IT and generally trailing -ly is unstressed. In terms of ease of writing, LOW-IT is very easily written cursively whereas LOW-EAT requires a break.

However, the word "creation" contains three distinct syllables - cre-a-tion so I would write this as KAY-ROE-EAT-ATE-SHE-NO.

I continue to maintain that QS should be written by users in their own method of speech, not using a rigid spelling system. I do accept, however, that in print there may need to be some level of standardisation in order to make reading easier. However, when I read print that attempts to mimic dialect or accent, I have no difficulty in understanding what is meant nor do I have difficulty in word recognition (which is the art of adult reading).

Word recognition, as has been shown by some of the silly circular emails where the letters are scrambled, depends largely upon the combination of consonants in the word with vowels taking a secondary place. We can quite easily decipher a word from the consonants only - for example: scrmbld cnsnts - the introduction of vowels just makes this process easier.

Orthodox script does not imply pronunciation of vowels - we all read the written word in our own dialect/accent. QS gives us more of an opportunity to express that dialect/accent to the reader. The fact that QS cannot in 40 letters represent all possible sounds is just not relevant - it does a much better job of it than orthodox script.

Moira

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Timothy" <tim_rice09@...> wrote:
>
> The reason I followed the convention of using IT for final, unstressed /i/ sounds is that the manual and Shavian writings before it reserve EAT for stressed /i/ (normally turned into the diphthong /ij/ or /iː/ or /ii̯/ (pick your notation poison) in most dialects). In QS, in the Call of Cthulhu you will also see that IT is used instead of EAT in places like the word "creation" that is spelled (we really need to make better names, folks) KAY ROE IT ATE SHE NO. This is because the stress falls on ATE. Also, since IT can be formed from either above or below, it really speeds up writing.
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@> wrote:
> >
> > Nathan Sharfi scripsit:
> >
> > > I was reading http://adiabatic.github.io/qs-literature/call-of-cthulhu/
> > > and noticed that many, if not all words ending in -ly were spelled
> > > -LOW IT instead of -LOW EAT. [...] Why would this spelling rule be
> > > put in? To save writers the trouble of lifting the pen when writing
> > > Senior Quikscript?
> >
> > No, it reflects Read's pronunciation. Since then, there's been a
> > sound change known as "happy-tensing", whereby final unstressed
> > "-y" (as in "happy") changed from IT to EAT. It's pervasive in
> > the Southern Hemisphere Englishes, very common in North America
> > (except for parts of the American South), and happened in the
> > RP accent within living memory. If you listen to the clip at
> > <http://www.hark.com/clips/wjprnvyxlm-my-name-is-jimmy-carter>,
> > you can hear former President (then future President) Jimmy
> > Carter saying his name "Jimmy", with the two vowels almost the same.
> >
> > Read was born in 1887, so he wouldn't have had happy-tensing -- all
> > his Quikscript represents really really conservative RP. That's why
> > he makes no distinction between NORTH words and FORCE words, but CURE
> > words are spelled differently.
> >
> > --
> > John Cowan cowan@ http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
> > O beautiful for patriot's dream that sees beyond the years
> > Thine alabaster cities gleam undimmed by human tears!
> > America! America! God mend thine every flaw,
> > Confirm thy soul in self-control, thy liberty in law!
> > --one of the verses not usually taught in U.S. schools
> >
>
